section.title: Can/can't, have to/don't have to
section.sectiontitle: Use can to say that something is possible or to give permission.
section.text2a: Hotel guests can use the health club next door.
section.sectiontitle2: Use can't to say that something isn't possible or isn't allowed. We often use can't to explain rules.
section.text4a: You can't drive through a red light.

section.title: Can/can't, have to/don't have to
section.sectiontitle: Use can to ask about rules and to ask for permission.
section.text1: You can take photographs in the museum.
section.text1a: Can we take photographs in the museum?
section.text2: You can leave your bags here.
section.text2a: Can we leave our bags here?

section.title: Can/can't, have to/don't have to
section.sectiontitle: Use have to when something is necessary. We usually use it to explain rules.
section.text1a: Visitors to India have to get a visa.
section.text2a: My brother has to do military service.
section.sectiontitle2: Use don't have to to say that something isn't necessary (but you can do it if you want to).
section.text3: Visitors to India have to get a visa.
section.text3a: Visitors to Spain from other parts of the EU don't have to get a visa.
section.text4: My brother has to do military service.
section.text4a: My sister doesn't have to do military service.
